Robust Engineering
Using Science, Statistics, and Critical Thinking to improve product design robustness

  • Glossary
  • Hypothesis Roadmap
  • Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis testing is a fundamental part of the scientific process where it is used to evaluate whether something being hypothesized is statistically valid or not.
Hypothesis testing is so named because the user has hypothesized about something and wants statistical evedence of the validity (or lack thereof) of The hypothesis. A Null Hypothesis (H0) and an Alternate Hypothesis (HA) are key element of every test. The nature of H0 is always based on the variation observed in the data being purely random (or "Nothing interesting going on") and HA is based on something else is going on. H0 and HA are always defined (at least in general) by the specific test being run and are not selectable by the user. The tests all provide a "p" statistic that represents The probability that H0 is TRUE. Decisions are ususally made based on P statistics and the value of p to use as the cutoff shoud be a carefully considered business decision. Typically, a value of .05 (5%) is used where if p is less that .05, H0 is rejected and it is assumed that HA is correct. Test selection is a function of the specifics of the data collected.

Roadmap for selecting Hypothesis testing tools

Type of data?
Attribute: Number of Factors?
Number of samples?
1-Proportion Test
H0: P1 = Pt
HA: P1 ≠ Pt
Test if the proportion (percent) of the population for a specific type of article (e.g. brand, color, material, etc.) meets a specification (e.g. 90% 0f parts must pass a test).
2-Proportion Test
H0: P1 = P2
HA: P1 ≠ P2
Test if the proportion (percent) of the population for two specific types of articles (e.g. brand, color, material, etc.) are equal (e.g. the odds of A and B are the same).
Contingency Table
H0: FA and FB are independant
HA: FA and FB are dependant
Test ...
Number of factors?
Is data Normal or Non-Normal?
Number of Levels?
Type of Test for 1 Level?
Chi2Test
H0: σ1 = σt
HA: σ1 ≠ σt
Determine if the variation for a specific type meets a specifaction - generally a maximum.
1 Sample t Test
H0: μ1 = μt
HA: μ1 ≠ μt
Determine if the avarage value for a specific type is within specifications (e.g. thickness within +/- spec limits)
Type of Test for 2 Levels?
F Test
H0: σ1 = σ2
HA: σ1 ≠ σ2
Determine if variation for two different types is equal
Is data independant?
2 Sample t Test
H0: μ1 = μ2
HA: μ1 ≠ μ2
Test if the avarage value for an attribute is the same for two specific types of items
Paired t Test
H0: μ1 = μ2
HA: μ1 ≠ μ2
Test if the average values for two specific types of items is the same when subjected to the same conditions (e.g. is shoe sole wear the same for the left and right shoes?)
Bartlets Test
H0: σ1 = σ2 = σ3
HA: σi ≠ σj for i ≠ j (or at least one is different)
Test if three or more specific types of items the same average values
Number of levels?
Test Type?
1-sample Wilcoxon or 1-Sample Significance
H0: M1 = Mt
HA: M1 ≠ Mt (t = target)
Test if the median value for a set of non-normally distributed data meets a specification
Chi2 Test
H0: σ1 = σt
HA: σ1 ≠ σt (t = target)
Test if the variation for a set of non-normally distributed data meets a specification
Levene's Test
H0: σ1 = σ2 = σ3 ...
HA: σi ≠ σj for i ≠ j (or at least 1 is different)
Test if central tendancies for 2 or more specific types of items are the same
Test Results?
2 Sample t Test
H0: μ1 = μt
HA: μ1 ≠ μt
Test ...
Number of Levels?
Mann-Whitney Test
H0: M1 = M2
HA: M1 ≠ M2
Test ...
Moods Median Test (used with outlier)
H0: M1 = M2 = M3...
HA: Mi ≠ Mj for i≠j (or at least 1 is different)
Test ...
Kruskal-Wallis Test (used with no outlier)
H0: M1 = M2 = M3...
HA: Mi ≠ Mj for i≠j (or at least 1 is different)
Test ...
ANOVA or Multiple Regression
Test ...
